Title: Gotcha
Reason(s): It was controversial due to the controls being perceived as pink rubber bulges that were meant to represent breasts and were squeezed in order to control the action.[1]

Title: Death Race
Reason(s): Violence (running over stickmen 'gremlins', who then scream)[2][3]

Title: Custer's Revenge
Reason(s): Nudity, rape, and racism[2][4][5]
A bishoujo game revolving around rape, it ignited a public furor that reached the National Diet of Japan.[6]

Title: J.B. Harold Murder Club
Reason(s): Sexual themes, including reference to an unsolved rape. [7]

Title: Mortal Kombat series
Reason(s): Blood, violence and gore. First fighter to introduce 'Fatalities' to finish off opponents[2][4][5][8][9][10]

Title: Night Trap
Reason(s): Violence, child abuse and sexual themes.[2][4][8]

Title: Doom
Reason(s): Violence, gore, and Satanic themes[2][5][8][9]

Title: SimCopter
Reason(s): A programmer named Jacques Servin introduced unauthorized 'bimbo' characters into the game, who would appear on certain dates and kiss.[11]

Title: Duke Nukem 3D
Reason(s): Violence, sexual themes, nudity.[12][13]

Title: Tomb Raider
Reason(s): An unauthorized software patch nicknamed 'Nude Raider' was created which allowed players to play as a nude version of Lara Croft.[14]

Title: Carmageddon
Reason(s): Violence against pedestrians[15]

Title: Postal
Reason(s): Violence[8]

Title: Grand Theft Auto series
Platform: PC, PS1, PS2, PS3, Xbox, Xbox 360
Reason(s): See also: Grand Theft Auto IV controversies Sexual themes, drug use, racism, nudity, language, drink driving, violence (against civilians and law enforcement officers; in Grand Theft Auto 3, there is also a cheat called 'Extra Gore Mode' in which, if you shoot at someone you can blow off their limbs), criminal behavior. Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas was originally rated 'Mature' in the US, but was re-rated 'Adults Only' after controversy surrounding a fanmade 'hot coffee mod' which unlocked a hidden sex scene (which was in the game's code, but left out of the final version). It was re-rated 'Mature' after Rockstar Games removed this scene from the game's code. Grand Theft Auto IV was referred to as a 'terrorist simulator' due to the fact that the city was loosely based on New York City.[2][4][8][16]

Title: Kingpin: Life of Crime
Reason(s): Violence[17]

Title: Ethnic Cleansing
Reason(s): Racially-motivated violence, white supremacist themes[18]

Title: State of Emergency
Reason(s): Contains military-style violence, including political assassinations and coup d'etats. Additionally, the game caused controversy in Washington due to the game's similarities to the World Trade Organization riots in Seattle.[19]

Title: Postal II
Reason(s): Violence against civilians (including LGBT and police officers), sexual themes, drug use, racism, language, animal abuse, and references to past and current events of terrorist attacks. Banned in New Zealand, Sweden and Australia.[20]

Title: Manhunt and Manhunt 2
Reason(s): Violence (allowed player to take the role of a serial killer). Gained significant controversy after it was alleged that the game inspired a teenager to commit a murder. Banned in Australia.[4][8][21]

Title: Dead or Alive Xtreme Beach Volleyball
Reason(s): Nudity and sexuality[5]

Title: The Sims 2
Reason(s): A cheat allows for the blur effect that appears when a character is nude to be removed.[22]

Title: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas
Reason(s): Main article: Hot Coffee mod An unauthorized 'Hot Coffee' mod unlocked a hidden sex scene left out of the game's final version. Was briefly re-rated 'Adults Only' by the ESRB, but had a 'Mature' rating reinstated after Rockstar Games removed this scene from the game's code in a different version.[23]

Title: Super Columbine Massacre RPG!
Reason(s): The game simulated the events of the Columbine High School shootings.[24][25][26][27]

Title: Bully
Reason(s): Violence in a school setting[8]

Title: The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion
Reason(s): Main article: ESRB re-rating of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Re-rated by the ESRB after a third-party mod revealed a nude topless graphic hidden in the game's data files. While the graphic did not warrant a re-rating of the game in and of itself, upon review, the ESRB noted that the game contained much more explicit violence than had been submitted to them in the original rating submission.[28]

Title: Hitman: Blood Money
Reason(s): Violence and assassinations; magazine ads for the game featured pictures depicting murder victims.[29]

Title: Mind Quiz
Reason(s): Recalled in the United Kingdom due to use of the word 'spastic', which is considered highly offensive in the UK.[30]

Title: Left Behind: Eternal Forces
Reason(s): Accusations that the game promoted religious 'convert or kill' violence, sexism and racism.[31][32][33] Some reviewers[34][35][36] denied that the game contained any truly controversial gameplay.

Title: Resistance: Fall of Man
Reason(s): Main article: Controversy over the usage of Manchester Cathedral in Resistance: Fall of Man The Church of England objected to the game's use of Manchester Cathedral's interior as a backdrop during a gun battle, and called for the game to be withdrawn or for the cathedral to be removed from the game.[37]

Title: RapeLay
Reason(s): Rape forms a core part of the gameplay leading to controversy raised in the UK Parliament and elsewhere.[38]

Title: Rule of Rose
Reason(s): The mayor of Rome called for the game to be banned from Italy, saying children 'have the right to be shielded from violence'.[39] The then European Union justice and security commissioner wrote an open letter condemning the game for 'obscene cruelty and brutality'. An Italian magazine, Panorama, claimed that in order to win the game players must bury a girl alive which the game's European publisher disputed.[40] On the UK release day, the publisher announced that Rule of Rose would not be published in the UK, despite the game being approved for release by the Pan European Game Information (PEGI) and Video Standards Council regulatory bodies.[41]

Title: BioShock
Reason(s): An article in The Patriot Ledger, the local paper of developer Irrational Games,[42] argued that the game is 'testing the limits of the ultraviolent gaming genre with a strategy that enables players to kill characters resembling young girls.'[43] The game presents an ethical choice to players, whether to kill 'Little Sisters' for extra abilities or save them and receive less. 2K president Ken Levine defended the game as a piece of art, stating 'we want to deal with challenging moral issues and if you want to do that, you have to go to some dark places'.[44] Jack Thompson took issue with advertisements for the game appearing during WWE SmackDown's airtime, writing to the Federal Trade Commission and stating that M-rated games should not be advertised when large numbers of under-17s are watching.[45]

Title: Mass Effect
Reason(s): Falsely accused by evangelical blogger Kevin McCullough of containing 'rape and sodomy', which later led to the removal of McCullough's blog entry on Townhall.com. The game was featured on the Fox News Channel following the controversy,[46] with Fox News host Martha MacCallum, which included the headline 'full graphic sex'.[47] In actuality, the game's most explicit content is an indirect 'sideboob' shot of a humanoid alien breast.[48]

Title: Mario Party 8
Reason(s): Use of the phrase 'Turn the train spastic! Make this ticket tragic!' by the character Kamek caused controversy in the United Kingdom, where the word spastic is considered offensive. This led to a recall of the game; it was later re-released with the word changed to erratic.[49]

Title: Muslim Massacre: The Game of Modern Religious Genocide
Reason(s): The game's contents and subject have been the subject of strong negative response; a spokesperson for the Muslim Council of Britain, said 'The makers of this 'game' and the ISPs [Internet service providers] who are hosting it should be quite ashamed of themselves. Anti-Muslim prejudice is already on the increase and needs to be challenged and not reinforced through tasteless and offensive stunts like this.'[50]

Title: LittleBigPlanet
Reason(s): Lyrics from a licensed song, 'Tapha Niang', were removed due to fears that Muslims would be offended. This led to controversy about the removal itself.[51]

Title: MadWorld
Reason(s): Violence. Described by the Daily Mail as the 'most violent video game ever'.[52]

Title: Resident Evil 5
Reason(s): For a pre-release trailer that contains scenes of racism,[53] according to Newsweek journalist N'Gai Croal in an April 2008 interview. He also stated that organizations and retailers would object to the game and that it would cause controversy on release.[53]

Title: Saw
Reason(s): Several news publishings stated that the game's only purpose was to torture and kill people in violent ways with no sense of restraint or morality. Some editorials called it 'depraved and inhumane' and stated that 'Konami should be ashamed'.[54] It was also listed in the 'Top ten most controversial games of 2009'.[55]

Title: Left 4 Dead 2
Reason(s): The cover art in the UK had to be altered due to a potentially offensive hand gesture being depicted.[56] The game was banned in Australia for its excessive violence and gore.[57] The game's New Orleans setting so soon after Hurricane Katrina was considered 'a bad call'.[58] Finally, Left 4 Dead 2 was accused of being racist after incorporating black infected into the game, Valve quickly stated this was only for population diversification purposes.[59]

Title: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2
Reason(s): Main article: Controversies surrounding Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 A level in the game entitled 'No Russian' has the player assume control of a deep cover Central Intelligence Agency agent, joining a group of Russian nationalist terrorists in enacting an airport massacre. The player is given the option to skip the level at any point.[60][61] The game was discussed briefly in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom after the issue was brought to the attention of MP Keith Vaz, a long time opponent of violence in video games, with fellow Labour Party politician Tom Watson arguing that the level was 'no worse than scenes in many films and books' and criticising Vaz for 'collaborating with the Daily Mail to create moral panic over the use of video games'.[62] The mission was removed in the Russian version of the game.[63]

Title: Six Days in Fallujah
Reason(s): The game was opposed by both the public and critics alike for 'glamorizing' and 'glossing over' the real-life Battle of Fallujah. This caused the former publisher, Konami, to oppose the game and stop publishing it.[64]

Title: Bulletstorm
Reason(s): Fox News Channel called out the title as the 'Worst Video Game in the World' due to the extreme amount of violence; claims made in the original article were dispelled by video game journalists including Rock Paper Shotgun, but Fox News continues to assert the game as too violent.[65]

Title: Call of Juarez: The Cartel
Reason(s): Residents of Ciudad Ju?rez and Mexico protested the announcement of the game, believing it to highlight the Ju?rez Cartel, who are believed responsible for over 3000 homicides in the city in 2010.[66]
